thread.section_title: Baseball and MLB News | Sports | Toronto Star
thread.title: Blue Jays look to make amends to their fans in Game 5
thread.title_full: Blue Jays look to make amends to their fans in Game 5 | Toronto Star

author: Brendan Kennedy
title: Blue Jays look to make amends to their fans in Game 5
text:
It’s important to breathe, Marcus Stroman said.
“Deep breaths.”
The Blue Jays’ ebullient right-hander was speaking of himself and how he would contain and control his emotions on the mound in Wednesday’s do-or-die Game 5 against the Texas Rangers.
But he could have been advising Jays’ fans across the city and the country, left gasping ever since this storybook season nearly came to an abrupt end mere days after it began.
Now, with a pair of encouraging victories — offensive breakthroughs recalling the bravado of the pre-playoff campaign — the Jays won the right to come home, to be embraced at least one more time by their frothing, desperate fan-base, yet to celebrate a playoff win on home soil since Joe Carter hooked his famous homer.
Their season may still be at the cliff’s edge, but they have a firmer toe-hold.
They owe their home crowd a better showing. Those series-opening losses were a shock to the system for most Jays’ fans, who had grown accustomed to the team’s relentless progression in the second half of the season.
One out of every 10 Canadians watched Sunday’s Game 3 victory from home. Hundreds made the trip to Arlington to be among the 50,000 at Globe Life Park.
If the inherent tension wasn’t enough, there is added controversy in the fact it will be Stroman and not David Price — the veteran ace — who makes the start after the latter was used in relief to secure a Game 4 win .
But Stroman, a budding ace in his own right, is no slouch and would be the first choice of many. His expressive presence on the mound both feeds and is fuelled by a charged crowd, and the Rogers Centre figures to be at full wattage.
“It’ll be fun,” said shortstop Troy Tulowitzki, the slump-busting hero of Game 3.
“It’s Game 5. It’s not quite a Game 7, but it’s as close as you can get to that. It’s do-or-die for both teams. As a kid, that’s what you dream about.”
Jays fans are hoping the dream will continue a little while longer.
